validation_note: The input data is strongly supported by the literature. Multiple studies confirm that Tau Tubulin Kinases 1 and 2 (TTBK1/TTBK2) are key kinases that directly phosphorylate TDP-43 at the pathological Ser409/410 sites. This action promotes TDP-43's mislocalization to the cytoplasm, its aggregation into inclusions, and subsequent neurotoxicity. The provided information is accurate and has been validated and supplemented with extensive evidence.

functions.cellular_process: Tau tubulin kinases 1 and 2 (TTBK1/TTBK2) directly phosphorylate TDP-43 at serines 409 and 410 (S409/S410), which are the hallmark pathological phosphorylation sites in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD-TDP).
functions.effect_description: Overexpression of TTBK1/2 robustly drives TDP-43 phosphorylation, causing it to shift from the nucleus to the cytoplasm and form inclusions. This phosphorylation causes TDP-43 to precipitate and aggregate, contributing to neurotoxicity. TTBK1/2 protein levels are elevated in FTLD-TDP patients, and the kinases co-localize with phosphorylated TDP-43 aggregates in ALS spinal cord tissue.
biological_consequence: Increased TTBK1/TTBK2 activity → Direct phosphorylation of TDP-43 at S409/S410 → TDP-43 cytoplasmic mislocalization and aggregation → Formation of pathological inclusions → Neurotoxicity and neurodegeneration
specific_effects: TTBK1 and TTBK2 directly phosphorylate TDP-43 in vitro.
Overexpression of TTBK1/2 in HEK293 cells induces robust TDP-43 phosphorylation and its recruitment into cytoplasmic inclusions.
TTBK1/2 co-localize with phospho-TDP-43 aggregates in brain and spinal cord tissue from FTLD-TDP and ALS patients.
Co-expression of TTBK1 with TDP-43 in C. elegans synergistically exacerbates behavioral abnormalities.
Phosphorylation by TTBK1/2 causes TDP-43 precipitation and aggregation in the cytoplasm of neurons.

evidence.paper_title: The Tau Tubulin Kinases TTBK1/2 Promote Accumulation of Pathological TDP-43
evidence.relevant_quote: we demonstrate TTBK1 and TTBK2 directly phosphorylate TDP-43 in vitro and promote TDP-43 phosphorylation in mammalian cultured cells.
evidence.authors: Nicole F Liachko, Patrick J McMillan, Laura J Taylor, Benjamin C Kraemer, et al.

evidence.paper_title: Pathological phosphorylation of tau and TDP-43 by TTBK1 and TTBK2 drives neurodegeneration
evidence.relevant_quote: Our recent work demonstrated that tau tubulin kinases 1 and 2 (TTBK1/2) robustly phosphorylate TDP-43 and co-localize with phosphorylated TDP-43 in human postmortem neurons from FTLD patients.
evidence.authors: Laura J Taylor, Nicole F Liachko, Patrick J McMillan, Brian C Kraemer

evidence.paper_title: Modulation of Tau Tubulin Kinases (TTBK1 and TTBK2) Impacts Ciliogenesis
evidence.relevant_quote: With respect to ALS and FTD, TTBK1 and TTBK2 phosphorylate TAR DNA binding protein of 43 kDa (TDP-43) both in vitro and in vivo... This phosphorylation causes TDP-43 precipitation and aggregation...
evidence.authors: Isabel M. Nozal, Laura C. C. de la Torre, Sara C. Garcia-Barrado, et al.

mechanism: Tau tubulin kinases 1 and 2 (TTBK1/TTBK2) directly phosphorylate TDP-43 at serines 409 and 410 (S409/S410), which are the hallmark pathological phosphorylation sites in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD-TDP).
effect: Overexpression of TTBK1/2 robustly drives TDP-43 phosphorylation, causing it to shift from the nucleus to the cytoplasm and form inclusions. This phosphorylation causes TDP-43 to precipitate and aggregate, contributing to neurotoxicity. TTBK1/2 protein levels are elevated in FTLD-TDP patients, and the kinases co-localize with phosphorylated TDP-43 aggregates in ALS spinal cord tissue.
summary: TDP43 activates TTBK1/TTBK2 to modulate tdp-43 phosphorylation, ultimately affecting neurotoxicity and neurodegeneration.
